description:
Lupinus albus, commonly known as the white lupin or field lupin, is a species of lupin that is native to the Mediterranean region. It is an annual herbaceous plant that can grow up to 1 meter tall.

The plant has palmately compound leaves with 5-11 leaflets. The flowers are white or pale blue and are arranged in dense, terminal racemes. The fruit is a legume pod that contains 3-5 large, flat, and white seeds.

Lupinus albus is cultivated for its edible seeds, which are high in protein, fiber, and other nutrients. The seeds are often used in traditional Mediterranean cuisines and can be processed into flour, oil, or other food products. The plant is also used as a cover crop or green manure due to its ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen in the soil.

Botanically, Lupinus albus belongs to the genus Lupinus, which is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae. The species is known for its adaptability to a range of soil types and its tolerance to drought and other environmental stresses.
